titleStmt.title: In the plentiful feast of romance
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln
titleStmt.funder: The National Endowment for the Humanities

address.addrLine: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: Edward Grier notes that "the writing [of this manuscript] suggests a date after 1860" (Notebooks and Unpublished Prose Manuscripts [New York: New York University Press, 1984] 4:1604). He also indicates that Richard Maurice Bucke, one of Whitman's literary executors, prints this manuscript along with several others, "with a note that they were intended for an unpublished essay" (4:1603).

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: "[Notes on Literature] (in Frey)"
bibl.orgName: Trent Collection of Whitmaniana, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

revisionDesc.change: created separate file for this transcription after the decision was made to separate this MS from duk.00112, with which it was previously grouped; added editorial note
checked, added brackets to title, added lasso on leaf001r, added milestone, changed "are" on leaf002r to "arc"

body.p: In the plentiful feast of romance presented to us, all Literature At present in through the whole arc of imaginative literature rises every where poems poetry &c All the novels, all the poems, really dish up is shows seems occupied by one ponly figure—our various forms or preparations of one only plot namely a sickly a desperatescrofulous crude amorousness love. It is a complaintmalady True the malady described is the "general one—it which all have to go through, on their way to real be eligible to Love, but this is not love.
